title: Did John Lennon's voice change at any time between when The Beatles started and when they finished? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the roughly 6 years that the Beatles recorded their entire catalogue, Lennon certainly became more experimental and outwardly expressive with his voice. Some examples are in his somewhat restrained but gravely, Dylanesque vocal delivery in “You’ve Got To Hide Your Love Away”, his almost glass-cutting, piercing tone in “A Day in the Life” and his raucous, mock-blues angst in “Yer Blues”. But from the very beginning John always had the most edgy, or raw sounding voice of the Beatles. This is evident in one of their earliest recording sessions - on “Twist and Shout” from their debut album “Please Please Me”. That edginess, combined with McCartney’s smoother sounding but extremely versatile voice helped define the Beatles sound (in terms of vocals). After the Beatles, Lennon’s voice noticeably changed in 1970 as a result of the primal therapy sessions he attended. Primal therapy was created by psychologist / psychotherapist Arthur Janov. Janov wrote a book called “The Primal Scream” in which he proposed that certain types of neurosis or emotional pain, often stemming from childhood trauma, could be treated or cured by patients screaming phrases such as “Mommy! Daddy!”. That therapy had a marked effect on John’s voice which can be heard on his solo album “Plastic Ono Band”, released in December 1970. Songs like “Mother” (during the outro) and a few others feature John screaming, but in a way that works musically, and has a stunning effect on the listener. The effectiveness of primal therapy, and whether that screaming had any long-term negative effects on Lennon’s voice, are controversial. However, they certainly helped make that album one of the greatest and most influential by any artist up to that point. The raw and authentic emotional expression in Lennon’s voice on that album can be heard in the works of later artists. Kurt Cobain is an excellent example, whether he was consciously emulating Lennon or not.

Well personally I’d say the answer to that question myself, would be yes. Not exactly a very strong yes, but there’s definitely something in his voice that changed at some point during the 60’s. Whether it’s because of drugs, alcohol, smoking, or just a result of getting older, I cannot say for certain. I know that he hated his voice and tried to make it sound different, but I’m pretty sure that can’t be the cause. His voice seemed to change a bit starting with “Rain”, though it’s not really until 1968 that I can really hear the difference between his pre-1966 voice and his post-1967 voice. Even on songs like “I’ll Cry Instead” where his voice is sorta scratchy, it’s not quite how it was on songs like “Hey Bulldog”. If you compare songs like “One After 909” (which was written a longtime before the other songs recorded around that time, in-fact the Let It Be sessions were not the first ones in which the song was recorded) with the songs that were both recorded and written as late as the early 60’s, you should be able to pick up some difference in his voice. Also if you compare John Lennon’s 1975 rock and roll album with the songs he covered while he was a Beatle in the early 60’s, there’s definitely some vocal differences there. And even if you compare his voice in ballads like “Woman” to his voice in ballads like “In My Life”.

Yes it did . When they started out they were doing So many gigs around Liverpool and the the UK his voice was somewhat “ earthy “ or “gravelly “. Obviously when your vocal chords get a thrashing singing songs like Rock and Roll music every night is going to take its toll. Later after success he had far more time to rest his voice so melodic renditions of “ beautiful boy “ etc seemed more smooth.
